Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rivers, Faults, and Growing Mountains: Dynamic Feedback between Crustal Deformation, Rock Strength, and Erosion
Award.AbstractNarration:
The topography of most active mountain ranges shows a clear link between deformation and erosion in the form of valley networks that align closely with faults and shear zones. We propose that this association is the signature of dynamic feedback between deformation, rock damage, and surface erosion, and that this feedback plays a fundamental role in the evolution of orogens. With this research program, we will test our hypothesis that the rock crushing associated with tectonically-driven earthquakes reduces the strength and grain size of the upper crust of the Earth, producing zones at the surface of material that is more readily eroded by rivers, landslides and glaciers. Erosion along these weakened fault zones proceeds more rapidly than the non-deformed material, and consequently, the deformation history is recorded within the topographic fabric. The 3D orientation of these fault-weakened zones is largely determined by large scale plate tectonics related to mantle convection. Consequently, if our hypothesis is sustained, then we will be able to use the orientation of surface features (valleys and ridges) to describe the long term history of mantle convection at relatively high resolution.

To test this hypothesis, we propose a program that combines advanced numerical modeling and field data collection in the Southern Alps of New Zealand to evaluate two testable predictions: (1) that there should exist a correlation between topography and rock strength, as reflected in properties such as bulk cohesion, fracture density, friction coefficient, tensile strength and grain size; and (2) that a coupled model of 3D deformation and erosion, based on our current understanding of the relevant physics, should produce patterns of topography, erosion, and strain that are both consistent with observations and substantially different from the case of uniform rock strength. We anticipate that this research will provide critical information for scientists working on the interdependence of surface and tectonic processes at scales ranging from those of mantle convection to those of individual drainage basins. As part of the outreach associated with this program, we will produce and test a Web-accessible landscape modeling module that will permit numerical experimentation by k12 and general audiences of landscape development in a simplified, coupled geomorphic/tectonic orogenic system.

This project is supported by the Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics program and the Tectonics program. In addition, this award is designated as an OIIA/ISE Global Venture Fund Award and is being co-funded by NSF's OIIA International Science and Engineering Section.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth’s landscape is characterized at all scales by a beguiling superposition of well-ordered features and very irregular or stochastic patterns. This topographic pattern, caused by interaction of tectonic and geomorphic processes, contains memory of the local climate and mechanical events that have shaped it. We pursued the hypothesis that the well-ordered structure in the topography resulted from a previously unrecognized coupling among the surface (or geomorphic) processes and the tectonic processes. This coupling, we proposed, arose from the role of rock damage that occurred during seismic events, fracturing and weakening the surface material, thereby, making it more readily eroded and deformed than the non-damaged rock. In order to evaluate this hypothesis, we first had to identify and quantify the degree to which the topography of mountain belts reflected an anisotropic fabric. To accomplish this, we designed software that could evaluate the correlation of topography at every point on Earth’s surface as a function of compass direction (azimuth) and also as a function of scale; (i.e. do valleys and ridges have a preferred direction at all scales or only at the largest scales?). This program, EVA, successfully identified the characteristic high degree of tectonic control at scales greater than ~ 10km and climate control dominance at smaller scales in natural topography.

The next step, once we had quantified the natural fabric anisotropy, was to evaluate the other component of the hypothesis that the topographic anisotropy arose in large part from fault damage and therefore provided important information about the tectonic history. To accomplish this, we combined two sets of software; a landscape evolution model developed by our collaborator, Greg Tucker, at the University of Colorado, with a three-dimensional mechanical model that we have modified and extensively used for geodynamic research. The major innovation here was to allow the strength of the material to evolve as a function of damage caused by deformation; i.e. along fault planes with an orientation predicted by our geodynamic models that were driven by far field mantle flow. The geodynamic models produced a strength anisotropy which the landscape models turned into a topographic anisotropy; i.e. fault damaged regions eroded more quickly producing orientations of ridges and valleys that reflected the pattern of fault damage. In addition, the weakening and removal of fault damaged material by erosion further focused deformation into those weakened regions, setting up another important feedback in the growth of mountains.

The successful evaluation of our hypothesis provides important information about the response of Earth’s surface to catastrophic events at increasingly shorter time and space scales. Firstly, landscape analyses that assume homogeneity lack the natural fabric of rock strength that we show to be critical for drainage pattern evolution and strain localization in orogens. Future studies using physics-based models of damage, detachment, and transport will be critical for future analysis of heterogeneous landscape evolution. Secondly, we can now make predictions about real Earth behavior that will have relevance to decisions that must be made by populations that exist where the competing effects of climate and tectonics control the short and long term local hazards (such as Himalayan countries, Taiwan, New Zealand, Alaska, California).

While pursuing the scientific challenges of this project, we have constructed teaching modules that investigate the same phenomenon for k12 and university audiences. These have been employed in undergraduate courses ERS 200) at the University ofMaine and in a CSDMS short course given by the funded graduate student responsible for much of the modeling development, S. Roy. Roy also has makes EVA generally available on request for research on anisotropic fabric of any surface. While developing this software, Roy served as mentor to several undergraduate students who have subsequently begun graduate studies related to topics funded by this grant.
